<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Ender_s_Game skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Ender's Game</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><dl>
<dd><i>This article is about the novel. For the 2013 film based on the novel, see <a href="/wiki/Ender%27s_Game_(film)" title="Ender's Game (film)">Ender's Game (film)</a>. For other uses, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ender%27s_Game_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ender's Game (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Ender's Game (disambiguation)</a>.</i>
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox book (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox book</a>
<i><b>Ender's Game</b></i> (1985) is a <a href="/wiki/Military_science_fiction" title="Military science fiction">military science fiction</a> novel by American author <a href="/w/index.php?title=Orson_Scott_Card&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Orson Scott Card (page does not exist)">Orson Scott Card</a>. Set in Earth's future, the novel presents an imperiled mankind after two conflicts with the "Buggers", an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Insectoid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Insectoid (page does not exist)">insectoid</a> alien species. In preparation for an anticipated third invasion, children, including the novel's protagonist, <a href="/wiki/Ender_Wiggin" title="Ender Wiggin">Ender Wiggin</a>, are trained at a very young age through increasingly difficult games including some in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Weightlessness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Weightlessness (page does not exist)">zero gravity</a>, where Ender's <a href="/wiki/Military_tactics" title="Military tactics">tactical</a> genius is revealed.
</p><p>The book originated as the short story "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ender%27s_Game_(short_story)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ender's Game (short story) (page does not exist)">Ender's Game</a>", published in the August 1977 issue of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Analog_Science_Fiction_and_Fact&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Analog Science Fiction and Fact (page does not exist)">Analog Science Fiction and Fact</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Elaborating on characters and plot lines depicted in the novel, Card later wrote additional books to form the <a href="/wiki/Ender%27s_Game_(series)" title="Ender's Game (series)">Ender's Game series</a>. Card released an updated version of <i>Ender's Game</i> in 1991, changing some political facts to reflect the times accurately; most notably, to include the collapse of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.
</p><p>Reception of the book has generally been positive, though some critics have denounced Card's perceived justification of his characters' violence.<sup id="cite_ref-Elaine_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elaine-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kessel_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kessel-3">[3]</a></sup> It has also become suggested reading for many military organizations, including the United States Marine Corps.<sup id="cite_ref-MarineC_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarineC-4">[4]</a></sup> <i>Ender's Game</i> won the 1985 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nebula_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nebula Award (page does not exist)">Nebula Award</a> for best novel<sup id="cite_ref-WWE-1985_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWE-1985-5">[5]</a></sup> and the 1986 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hugo Award (page does not exist)">Hugo Award</a> for best novel.<sup id="cite_ref-WWE-1986_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWE-1986-6">[6]</a></sup> Its sequels, <i><a href="/wiki/Speaker_for_the_Dead" title="Speaker for the Dead">Speaker for the Dead</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Xenocide" title="Xenocide">Xenocide</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Children_of_the_Mind" title="Children of the Mind">Children of the Mind</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ender_in_Exile&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ender in Exile (page does not exist)">Ender in Exile</a></i>, follow Ender's subsequent travels to many different worlds in the galaxy. In addition, the later novella <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_War_of_Gifts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A War of Gifts (page does not exist)">A War of Gifts</a></i> and novel <i><a href="/wiki/Ender%27s_Shadow" title="Ender's Shadow">Ender's Shadow</a></i> take place during the same time period as the original. <i>Ender's Game</i> has been adapted into two comic series.
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Ender%27s_Game_(film)" title="Ender's Game (film)">film adaptation of the same name</a> directed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gavin_Hood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gavin Hood (page does not exist)">Gavin Hood</a> and starring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asa_Butterfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asa Butterfield (page does not exist)">Asa Butterfield</a> as Ender was released in October 2013. Card co-produced the film.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</li>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Creation_and_inspiration">Creation and inspiration</span></h2>
<p>The original <a href="/wiki/Novella" title="Novella">novelette</a> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ender%27s_Game_(short_story)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ender's Game (short story) (page does not exist)">Ender's Game</a>" provides a small snapshot of Ender's experiences in Battle School and Command School; the full-length novel encompasses more of Ender's life before, during, and after the war, and also contains some chapters describing the political exploits of his older siblings back on Earth. In a commentary track for the 20th Anniversary audiobook edition of the novel, as well as in the 1991 Author's Definitive Edition, Card stated that <i>Ender's Game</i> was written specifically to establish the <a href="/wiki/Character_(arts)" title="Character (arts)">character</a> of Ender for his role of the Speaker in <i><a href="/wiki/Speaker_for_the_Dead" title="Speaker for the Dead">Speaker for the Dead</a></i>, the outline for which he had written before novelizing <i>Ender's Game</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-book_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-book-8">[8]</a></sup> In his 1991 introduction to the novel, Card discussed the influence of <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Asimov" title="Isaac Asimov">Isaac Asimov's</a> <a href="/wiki/Foundation_series" title="Foundation series">Foundation series</a> on the novelette and novel. Historian <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Catton" title="Bruce Catton">Bruce Catton</a>'s work on the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> also influenced Card heavily.<sup id="cite_ref-book_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-book-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Ender's Game</i> was the first science-fiction novel published entirely online, when it appeared on <a href="/wiki/Delphi_(online_service)" title="Delphi (online service)">Delphi</a> a year before print publication.<sup id="cite_ref-dignazio198612_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dignazio198612-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Synopsis">Synopsis</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ender%27s_Game_chronology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ender's Game chronology (page does not exist)">Template:Ender's Game chronology</a>
</p><p>Humanity, having begun to explore the <a href="/wiki/Universe" title="Universe">Universe</a> and master <a href="/wiki/Interplanetary_spaceflight" title="Interplanetary spaceflight">interplanetary spaceflight</a>, has encountered an alien race known as the "buggers" (known in later books as the 'Formics'), scouting the system and establishing a forward base in the asteroid <a href="/wiki/433_Eros" title="433 Eros">Eros</a>, who provoked two drawn-out wars. Despite political conflict on Earth between three ruling parties (the Hegemon, Polemarch, and Strategos), a peace was established and an International Fleet (IF) formed against the Buggers.  In preparation for the Buggers' return (dubbed the "third invasion") the IF created the Battle School, a program designed to subject children with the best tactical minds to rigorous training.
</p><p>Protagonist <a href="/wiki/Ender_Wiggin" title="Ender Wiggin">Andrew "Ender" Wiggin</a> is one of the school's trainees; but despite this, is teased as a "Third" under Earth's two-child policy. He has a close bond with his sister <a href="/wiki/Valentine_Wiggin" title="Valentine Wiggin">Valentine</a>, but fears his brother <a href="/wiki/Peter_Wiggin" title="Peter Wiggin">Peter</a>, a highly intelligent <a href="/wiki/Antisocial_personality_disorder" title="Antisocial personality disorder">sociopath</a>.  After the IF removes Ender's monitoring device, presumably ending his chances of Battle School, he fights a fellow student, Stilson. Though the weaker of the two, Ender fatally wounds Stilson, but is left unaware of doing so. When explaining his actions to IF Colonel <a href="/wiki/Hyrum_Graff" title="Hyrum Graff" class="mw-redirect">Hyrum Graff</a>, Ender states his belief that, by showing superiority now, he has prevented future struggle. Graff, on hearing of this, offers Ender a place in the Battle School, situated in Earth's orbit, where Graff quickly isolates Ender from the other cadets, but encourages him to continue training despite frustration, through communications from Valentine.
</p><p>The cadets participate in competitive war simulations in zero gravity, wherein Ender's innovations disrupt the standard operations.  Graff promotes Ender to a new army composed of the newest and youngest cadets, which Ender leads to the top of the school. There, Ender fights Bonzo Madrid, a jealous commander of another army, outside the simulation, and unknowingly kills him. Under Ender's leadership, several of his current and former squad members form <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Battle_School_students&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Battle School students (page does not exist)">'Ender's Jeesh'</a> that remain loyal to him.
</p><p>On Earth, Peter Wiggin has used a global communication system to post political essays under the pseudonym "<a href="/wiki/John_Locke" title="John Locke">Locke</a>", hoping to establish himself as a respected orator and thence as a powerful politician. Valentine, despite not trusting Peter, publishes works alongside his as "<a href="/wiki/Demosthenes" title="Demosthenes">Demosthenes</a>". Their essays are soon taken seriously by the government. Though Graff is told their true identities, he recommends that it be kept a secret, because their writings are politically useful.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Command_School">Command School</span></h3>
<p>Ender, now ten years old, is soon promoted to Command School (on asteroid <a href="/wiki/433_Eros" title="433 Eros">433 Eros</a>), skipping several years of schooling. There, he is tutored by a former war hero, <a href="/wiki/Mazer_Rackham" title="Mazer Rackham" class="mw-redirect">Mazer Rackham</a>. Alongside other training activities, Mazer sets virtual fleets under Ender's control against Bugger fleets controlled by Mazer. Ender adapts to the game and, as the simulations become harder, receives members of his Jeesh as sub-commanders. Despite this, Ender becomes depressed by the simulations, by his isolation from others, and by his treatment by Mazer.
</p><p>When told by Mazer that he is facing his final test, Ender finds his human fleet far-outnumbered by the Buggers and sacrifices most of his fighters to launch a Molecular Disruption Device, capable of destroying the entire planet, intending to earn himself expulsion from the school for his ruthlessness. The Device destroys the planet and the entire Bugger fleet, but as the simulation ends, Ender is surprised to find the IF commanders celebrating. Mazer returns, and informs Ender that this – and earlier skirmishes in the "simulator" – were not simulation, but the actual IF contingent and the Buggers' main fleet at their homeworld, and with their destruction Ender has terminated the war. Ender becomes more depressed on learning this and of the deaths of Stilson and Bonzo.
</p><p>When he recovers, he finds himself still in orbit with his closest friends and learns that, at the end of the Bugger war, Earth's powers fought among themselves. He stays on Eros as his friends return home and colonists venture to other worlds, using Eros as a way station. Among the first colonists is his sister, Valentine, who apologizes that Ender can never return to Earth, where he would become dangerous as used by the various leaders, including Peter. Instead, Ender joins the colony program to populate one of the Buggers' former worlds. There, he discovers the dormant egg of a Bugger queen.  The queen, through telepathy, explains that the Buggers had initially assumed humans were a non-sentient race, for want of <a href="/wiki/Collective_consciousness" title="Collective consciousness">collective consciousness</a>, but realized their mistake too late, and requests that Ender take the egg to a new planet to colonize.
</p><p>Ender takes the egg and, with information from the Queen, writes <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Hive_Queen_(Ender%27s_Game)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Hive Queen (Ender's Game) (page does not exist)">The Hive Queen</a></i> under the alias "<a href="/wiki/Speaker_for_the_Dead" title="Speaker for the Dead">Speaker for the Dead</a>". Peter, now the <a href="/wiki/Hegemon" title="Hegemon" class="mw-redirect">Hegemon</a> of Earth, recognizes Ender's work and requests Ender to write a book about him, which Ender entitles <i>Hegemon</i>. The combined works create a new type of funeral, in which the Speaker for the Dead tells the whole and unapologetic story of the deceased, that is adopted by many on Earth and its colonies. In the end, Ender and Valentine board a series of starships and visit many worlds, looking for a safe place to establish the unborn Hive Queen.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Critical_response">Critical response</span></h2>
<p>Critics have generally received <i>Ender's Game</i> well.  The novel won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nebula_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nebula Award (page does not exist)">Nebula Award</a> for best novel in 1985,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hugo Award (page does not exist)">Hugo Award</a> for best novel in 1986,<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> considered the two most prestigious awards in science fiction.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>  <i>Ender's Game</i> was also nominated for a Locus Award in 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-WWE-1986_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWE-1986-6">[6]</a></sup> In 1999, it placed #59 on the reader's list of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Modern_Library_100_Best_Novels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Modern Library 100 Best Novels (page does not exist)">Modern Library 100 Best Novels</a>. It was also honored with a spot on <a href="/wiki/American_Library_Association" title="American Library Association">American Library Association</a>'s "100 Best Books for Teens."  In 2008, the novel, along with <i><a href="/wiki/Ender%27s_Shadow" title="Ender's Shadow">Ender's Shadow</a></i>, won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Margaret_A._Edwards_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Margaret A. Edwards Award (page does not exist)">Margaret A. Edwards Award</a>, which honors an author and specific works by that author for lifetime contribution to young adult literature.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> <i>Ender's Game</i> was included in <a href="/wiki/Damien_Broderick" title="Damien Broderick">Damien Broderick</a>'s book <i>Science Fiction: The 101 Best Novels 1985–2010</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Times" title="New York Times" class="mw-redirect">New York Times</a></i> writer Gerald Jonas asserts that the novel's plot summary resembles a "grade Z, made-for-television, science-fiction rip-off movie", but says that Card develops the elements well despite this "unpromising material". Jonas further praises the development of the character <a href="/wiki/Ender_Wiggin" title="Ender Wiggin">Ender Wiggin</a>:  "Alternately likable and insufferable, he is a convincing little <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> in short pants."<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>The novel has received negative criticism for violence and its justification. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elaine_Radford&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elaine Radford (page does not exist)">Elaine Radford</a>'s review, "Ender and Hitler: Sympathy for the Superman", posits that Ender Wiggin is an intentional reference by Card to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> and criticizes the violence in the novel, particularly at the hands of the protagonist.<sup id="cite_ref-Elaine_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elaine-2">[2]</a></sup> Card responded to Radford's criticisms in <i>Fantasy Review</i>, the same publication. Radford's criticisms are echoed in <a href="/wiki/John_Kessel" title="John Kessel">John Kessel</a>'s essay "Creating the Innocent Killer: Ender's Game, Intention, and Morality", wherein Kessel states: "Ender gets to strike out at his enemies and still remain morally clean.  <i>Nothing</i> is his fault."<sup id="cite_ref-Kessel_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kessel-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/U.S._Marine_Corps" title="U.S. Marine Corps" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Marine Corps</a> Professional Reading List makes the novel recommended reading at several lower ranks, and again at Officer Candidate/Midshipman.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
The book was placed on the reading list by Captain <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_F._Schmitt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John F. Schmitt (page does not exist)">John F. Schmitt</a>, author of FMFM-1 (Fleet Marine Fighting Manual, on maneuver doctrine) for "provid[ing] useful allegories to explain why militaries do what they do in a particularly effective shorthand way."<sup id="cite_ref-USMCEnders3_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USMCEnders3-18">[18]</a></sup>
In introducing the novel for use in leadership training, Marine Corps University's Lejeune program opines that it offers "lessons in training methodology, leadership, and ethics as well [....] <i>Ender's Game</i> has been a stalwart item on the Marine Corps Reading List since its inception."<sup id="cite_ref-USMCEnders3_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USMCEnders3-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Accolades">Accolades</span></h2>

</td>

</td></tr></table>
<p>The weeks ending June 9, August 18, September 8, September 15, November 3, November 10, November 17, and November 24, 2013, the novel was #1 on the New York Times' Best Sellers List of Paperback Mass-Market Fiction.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Revisions">Revisions</span></h2>
<p>In 1991, Card made several minor changes to reflect the political climates of the time, including the decline of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>. In the afterword of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ender_in_Exile&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ender in Exile (page does not exist)">Ender in Exile</a></i>, Card stated that many of the details in chapter 15 of <i>Ender's Game</i> were modified for use in the subsequent novels and short stories.  In order to more closely match the other material, Card has rewritten chapter 15, and plans to offer a revised edition of the book.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Adaptations">Adaptations</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Film">Film</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 2011, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Summit_Entertainment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Summit Entertainment (page does not exist)">Summit Entertainment</a> financed and coordinated the film's development and served as its distributor.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gavin_Hood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gavin Hood (page does not exist)">Gavin Hood</a> directed the film which lasts 1 hour 54 minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> Filming began in <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans,_Louisiana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Orleans, Louisiana (page does not exist)">New Orleans, Louisiana</a>, on February 27, 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> and was released on November 1, 2013 (USA).<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> A movie preview trailer<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> was released in May 2013 and a second trailer<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> was released later that year.
</p><p>Card has called <i>Ender's Game</i> "unfilmable", "because everything takes place in Ender's head", and refused to sign a film deal unless he could ensure that the film was "true to the story". Of the film that he eventually agreed to, Card said it was "the best that good people could do with a story they really cared about and believed in" and while warning fans not to expect a completely faithful adaptation, called the film "damn good".<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Video_game">Video game</span></h3>
<p><i>Ender's Game: Battle Room</i> was a planned digitally distributed <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">video game</a> for all viable downloadable platforms.<sup id="cite_ref-devdiscuss_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-devdiscuss-43">[43]</a></sup> It was under development by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chair_Entertainment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chair Entertainment (page does not exist)">Chair Entertainment</a>, which also developed the Xbox Live Arcade games <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Undertow_(video_game)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Undertow (video game) (page does not exist)">Undertow</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shadow_Complex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shadow Complex (page does not exist)">Shadow Complex</a></i>. Chair had sold the licensing of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Empire_(2006_novel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Empire (2006 novel) (page does not exist)"><i>Empire</i></a> to Card, which became a best-selling novel. Little was revealed about the game, save its setting in the Ender universe and that it would have focused on the Battle Room.<sup id="cite_ref-devdiscuss_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-devdiscuss-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December, 2010, it was announced that the video game development had stopped and the project put on indefinite hold.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Comics">Comics</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">Marvel Comics</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Orson_Scott_Card&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Orson Scott Card (page does not exist)">Orson Scott Card</a> announced on April 19, 2008, that they would be publishing a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Limited_series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Limited series (page does not exist)">limited series</a> adaptation of <i>Ender's Game</i> as the first in a comic series that would adapt all of Card's <i>Ender's Game</i> novels.  Card was quoted as saying that it is the first step in moving the story to a visual medium.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> The first five-issue series, titled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ender_Comics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ender Comics (page does not exist)">Ender's Game: Battle School</a></i>, was written by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christopher_Yost&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christopher Yost (page does not exist)">Christopher Yost</a>, while the second five-issue series, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ender_Comics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ender Comics (page does not exist)">Ender's Shadow: Battle School</a></i>, was written by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mike_Carey_(British_writer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mike Carey (British writer) (page does not exist)">Mike Carey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Audioplay">Audioplay</span></h3>
<p><i>Ender's Game Alive: The Full Cast Audioplay</i>, is an <a href="/wiki/Radio_drama" title="Radio drama">audio drama</a> written by Orson Scott Card, based on the <i>Ender's Game</i> novel. At over seven hours in length, this retelling of <i>Ender's Game</i> hints at story lines from "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Teacher%27s_Pest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Teacher's Pest (page does not exist)">Teacher's Pest</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Polish_Boy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Polish Boy (page does not exist)">The Polish Boy</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Gold_Bug_(short_story)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Gold Bug (short story) (page does not exist)">The Gold Bug</a>", <i><a href="/wiki/Ender%27s_Shadow" title="Ender's Shadow">Ender's Shadow</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Shadow_of_the_Hegemon" title="Shadow of the Hegemon">Shadow of the Hegemon</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Shadow_of_the_Giant" title="Shadow of the Giant">Shadow of the Giant</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shadows_in_Flight&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shadows in Flight (page does not exist)">Shadows in Flight</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Earth_Unaware&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earth Unaware (page does not exist)">Earth Unaware</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Speaker_for_the_Dead" title="Speaker for the Dead">Speaker for the Dead</a></i>, and gives new insight into the beginnings of Ender's philotic connection with the Hive Queen.
</p><p><i>Ender's Game Alive</i> is directed by Gabrielle de Cuir, produced by Stefan Rudnicki at Skyboat Media, published by <a href="/wiki/Audible.com" title="Audible.com">Audible.com</a>, and performed by a cast of over 30 voice actors playing over 100 roles.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Translations">Translations</span></h2>
<p><i>Ender's Game</i> has been translated into 34 languages:
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col (page does not exist)">Template:Div col</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-sq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-sq (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-sq</a> ("Ender's Game").
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Language_with_name&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Language with name (page does not exist)">Template:Language with name</a> ("Ender's Game").
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Zh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Zh (page does not exist)">Template:Zh</a> (<i>Āndé de yóuxì</i>) ("Ender's Game"), 2003.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-hr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-hr (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-hr</a> ("Ender's Game"), 2007.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-cs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-cs (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-cs</a> ("Ender's Game"), 1994.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a> ("Ender's Strategy"), 1990.

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-ja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-ja (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-ja</a> (<i>Endā no Gēmu</i>) ("Ender's Game"), 1987.

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-ro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-ro (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-ro</a> ("Ender's Game").
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Language_with_name&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Language with name (page does not exist)">Template:Language with name</a> ("Ender's Game"), 1995, 1996, 2002, 2003 (two editions).
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-sl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-sl (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-sl</a> ("Ender's Game"), 2010.

<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-sr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-sr (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-sr</a> ("Ender's Game"), 1988.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-es&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-es (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-es</a> ("Ender's Game").
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-sv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-sv (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-sv</a> ("Ender's Game"), 1991, 1998.

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-tr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-tr (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-tr</a> ("Ender's Game").
</li>

</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col_end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col end (page does not exist)">Template:Div col end</a>
</p>

</li>

</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.hatrack.com/osc/books/endersgame/endersgame.shtml">About the novel <i>Ender's Game</i> from Card's website</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.isfdb.org/cgi-bin/title.cgi?2004"><i>Ender's Game</i></a> title listing at the <a href="/wiki/Internet_Speculative_Fiction_Database" title="Internet Speculative Fiction Database">Internet Speculative Fiction Database</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.intergalacticmedicineshow.com/">Intergalactic Medicine Show</a>: Online science fiction magazine published by Orson Scott Card. Features a new Ender's world story in every issue.
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Orson_Scott_Card&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Orson Scott Card (page does not exist)">Template:Orson Scott Card</a>
